dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: An eighty-five billion dollar company, just briefly becoming the most valuable in all of Canada. That's Shopify we're talking about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: An eighty-five billion dollar company, just briefly becoming the most valuable in all of Canada. That's Shopify we're talking about.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its value peaked at $84 billion last week, briefly making it the most valuable company in Canada, and pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's pushed their CEO, Tobias Lütke, to a net worth of over six point two billion. But for one of their earliest investors, Bessemer Venture Partners, this whole story is kinda bittersweet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's pushed their C E O, Tobias Lütke, to a net worth of over six point two billion. But for one of their earliest investors, Bessemer Venture Partners, this whole story is kinda bittersweet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its value peaked at $84 billion last week, briefly making it the most valuable company in Canada, and pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they put in five point seven million initially and built up a twenty-seven percent stake. But then, as is pretty typical for venture capital, they cashed out after the IPO.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they put in five point seven million initially and built up a twenty-seven percent stake. But then, as is pretty typical for venture capital, they cashed out after the I P O.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The firm first invested $5.5 million in the companys initial funding round, and after additional investments built a 26% stake worth $500 million when it went public in 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: By the end of 2019, they'd redistributed all their shares back to their partners. And at that time, Shopify was valued at sixteen billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: By the end of twenty nineteen, they'd redistributed all their shares back to their partners. And at that time, Shopify was valued at sixteen billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though as is the typical modus operandi of venture capital firms hold onto investments while the company scales and cash out following an IPO Bessemer had redistributed all its shares back to its partners by the end of 2018, when the company was worth $15 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which sounds like a huge win, right? But if they'd held on until now... their stake would be worth close to twenty-three billion today.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which sounds like a huge win, right? But if they'd held on until now... their stake would be worth close to twenty-three billion today.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today Bessemers stake would currently be worth close to $22 billion, the firm says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh man, that means they left over eighteen billion dollars on the table. I mean, that's just... staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh man, that means they left over eighteen billion dollars on the table. I mean, that's just... staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By exiting Shopify two years ago, Bessemer left at least $17 billion on the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led that initial funding round, said he just couldn't comprehend that level of success back then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led that initial funding round, said he just couldn't comprehend that level of success back then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I couldnt comprehend that they would have this massive amount of success at that time, says Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led Shopifys initial funding round in 2010.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And you know, a global pandemic wasn't exactly in anyone's forecast. It forced so many brick-and-mortar retailers online, which just supercharged demand for Shopify's tools.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And you know, a global pandemic wasn't exactly in anyone's forecast. It forced so many brick-and-mortar retailers online, which just supercharged demand for Shopify's tools.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the past month, Shopifys share price has doubled after it generated $470 million in revenue in the first quarter, as demand for its online tools has skyrocketed from brick-and-mortar retailers who have been forced online by the COVID-19 pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Their revenue hit four hundred eighty million in the first quarter alone, and the share price grew by a hundred and ten percent in just the past month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Their revenue hit four hundred eighty million in the first quarter alone, and the share price grew by a hundred and ten percent in just the past month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the past month, Shopifys share price has doubled after it generated $470 million in revenue in the first quarter, as demand for its online tools has skyrocketed from brick-and-mortar retailers who have been forced online by the COVID-19 pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Will Gornall, a professor at UBC, pointed out that it's rare for a VC firm to even build such a large stake in a hot startup like that. So this really stands out as a massive missed opportunity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Will Gornall, a professor at U B C, pointed out that it's rare for a V C firm to even build such a large stake in a hot startup like that. So this really stands out as a massive missed opportunity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even though a global pandemic does not factor into the forecast of most investors, Bessemers stake in Shopify stands out as a significant missed opportunity in venture investing because it is rare that a venture capital firm would have built such a large stake in a hot startup, says Will Gornal, a professor at the University of British Columbias Sauder Business School.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But venture funds are under pressure to post returns within five to ten years. They're not really set up to hold for the long haul like public market investors might.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But venture funds are under pressure to post returns within five to ten years. They're not really set up to hold for the long haul like public market investors might.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Venture capital funds are typically under pressure to post returns on investments in private startups over a relatively short period of time, between five and 10 years, says Gornal. This kind of mission isnt conducive to reaping bigger returns that come years after a public offering, like those generated by other tech giants such as Amazon and Google.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True. And hey, they still made between eighty and a hundred times their initial investment. Ferrara said they didn't have a crystal ball, and they'll gladly take those returns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True. And hey, they still made between eighty and a hundred times their initial investment. Ferrara said they didn't have a crystal ball, and they'll gladly take those returns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Bessemers one-time stake in Shopify might prove a once-in-a-lifetime type tech position, Ferrara says the firm will gladly take its realized returns on the deal: between 80x and 100x its initial investment. Says the venture capitalist: We didnt have a crystal ball.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still though... twenty-three billion. I think I'd be kicking myself a little bit every single day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still though... twenty-three billion. I think I'd be kicking myself a little bit every single day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. But you know, they're not alone. Felicis Ventures also invested early and redistributed their shares before the real boom.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. But you know, they're not alone. Felicis Ventures also invested early and redistributed their shares before the real boom.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Bessemer is not alone among early investors in Shopify for exiting the company before the height of its riches were truly clear. Felicis Ventures, which invested alongside Bessemer in 2010, has since redistributed its shares back to its limited partners, the firm says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's one of those classic 'what if' stories in investing. Just wild how timing and holding periods can change everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's one of those classic 'what if' stories in investing. Just wild how timing and holding periods can change everything.
